transcription.text: [ Music ]
>> So, as you all know, Microsoft is our premier sponsor of DevCon 2.
And Marley Gray, who is of blockchain engineering,
and the head of blockchain engineering, is here to both speak
and give an introduction.
And come on up, Marley.
Give a hand for Marley Gray, please, Microsoft.
[ Applause ]
>> Thanks, man.
[ Applause ]
>> Good morning.
>> Good morning.
>> I think I should thank Roman for getting you guys wasted last night.
So, nobody's here this morning to see this.
So, the title of the speech this morning is a lap-of-one cripple.
But what I really want to do is take a trip down memory lane,
which was late July 2015 when Frontier was released,
was when we officially started playing with Ethereum,
such that we then launched with Ethereum together.
Using with our partners consensus and started down the Ethereum blockchain as a service.
So, I always feel like the journey with a lot of people in point
to Microsoft being an early adopter of Bitcoin,
that was sort of an experiment, our learning lesson for us
to really embrace Ethereum.
So, I don't want to tell you what I had to go through to get the sponsorship
for last year's DevCon.
It was not pretty.
This year's DevCon sponsorship was quite easy.
For me to do, it's a lot more money as well.
But Ethereum, just to set the stage here for Microsoft's commitment here,
is Ethereum is a first-class citizen and will continue to be a first-class citizen
in our distributed ledger efforts at Microsoft.
And it dominates our marketplace.
And our customers are using it and asking us.
And with that, I've got some things we're doing.
I have a lot of partners in the room.
I think almost everyone should be a partner if you're not.
Please talk to your Microsoft representative.
If you're a small startup, we have programs called Bizpark.
I know a lot of you have taken advantage of that.
Encourage you to do that.
And we'll be talking some more about the other things later.
But this morning, I want to announce, the project announced,
Blutchly version 1. So Blutchly is our code name for everything blockchain at Microsoft.
And let me explain a little bit about that is, and I'm going to walk you through what V1 means.
But Blutchly, the architectural diagram over here is sort of the big picture.
And you'll see Ethereum is quite prominent here.
So our distributed ledger stack down at the bottom, this is what we call our distributed infrastructure,
or Blutchly distributed infrastructure.
We are shipping version 1, a consortium, Ethereum private network starter.
So you can go on Ethereum, any customer can, instead of just spinning up a single node or a single DevTest lab,
you can actually spin up a full consortium network.
I'll go through exactly what that means a little bit later on.
You'll see this in the press.
We released these announcements this morning.
It's timed with this keynote.
It's hard to time those things all up at four o'clock in the morning.
Said I know you were up at like three working on this stuff.
So we'll walk through this, but Ethereum is the first class.
We're going to walk through that.
I'm going to first walk you through Criplets.
So we introduced Criplets in June as a middleware approach for bringing
much change into the enterprise. All of our interest from our major enterprises are trying to figure out how
consortiums will get together to take advantage of this distributed network promise.
So Criplets is how we sort of get our head around this.
We'll look at it as a new tier.
So those of you that have some gray hair, we'll remember the pain we went through and went from client server
to three tiered architecture in the web, very similar to the pain that we're experiencing in the growing pains
within distributed ledgers or blockchains.
And so there's a lot of missing parts that enterprises want.
They want things like some of you'll call an Illities list, but it's essentially scalability,
manageability, you know, those types of things.
So we identified these key things like identity, existing systems integration, key management,
not just storing your keys, but managing the entire lifecycle of your keys.
It's a very difficult thing to do and do correctly.
Security in depth, just a number of talks yesterday on security.
I don't think we even had a topic on it last year.
Maybe one or two.
But we're really getting to the point where people can start building solutions,
industry-specific solutions, financial services is the largest, but we're going to see them in health care,
media, supply chains, huge, all over the place.
So Cripluses are sort of our catch-all for delivering these capabilities in the cloud.
So with the introduction of Oracle's, how do you get data injected or real-world data injected into a blockchain?
Oracle's came out, but it's more than just trusted data.
It's how do you get trusted execution?
We need a very flexible and malleable execution platform, where you as an architect or a developer
can make the right decisions based on what you're trying to do and have clean separation of
concerns in your code, which is something in the enterprise is paid a lot of attention to.
So things like doing things at specific times or specific intervals, doing things based on
triggers, you can have market watches, you want to be able to also protect IP.
If you have algorithms that you have, you don't want those algorithms in the clear on the blockchain,
you want to protect those.
You might want to scale an algorithm.
You might want to have better performance and a blockchain can offer you.
How do you achieve that while still getting the benefit of a distributed ledger?
And then complex interactions.
When we start getting into enterprise systems, you get into complex distributed transaction
coordination, where you're not just updating a Ethereum network.
You might be updating a CRM system, old host, mainframe system, an Oracle database,
a CRM system, and the Ethereum blockchain system in a single transaction.
How do you do that?
Well, we actually know how to do that.
And that technology has been around since the turning part of the century,
because we had to go through those grain panes when we went to the web.
So we want to be able to use those things and also use libraries like .NET and Java and
pick your platform to yours.
Not just going to be about single language development.
We need choice, choice and platform and choice and language.
So I'll put this in here.
I'm not going to go through this chart.
Some of the things that Cripplet's, I'll go through the key points.
For this audience, getting secure data and Oracle's have been around for some time.
It's still a new concept for a lot of people.
How do you get real world data in there?
Oracle's really don't provide a standard way for you to have attestation of that data.
Cripplet provides that to you by default.
But Cripplet's does more than that.
It's more than secure data.
It's also secure execution.
How can you enlist complex execution tasks off the chain while keeping that integrated developer
and business and operational experience and also create a marketplace for developers in this
audience?
You might come up with Cripplet ideas to create a Cripplet library that you can put in the marketplace
and sell to a specific industry.
They can be vertical and horizontal in nature.
So there's a lot of infrastructure here that we're building to wire this up.
We are making our goal is for the Cripplet fabric.
That's what we're calling it, the blockchain Cripplet fabric.
To be easily consumed by developers, you'll be simply being able to make or discover
Cripplets out in the marketplace, references to them, declaratively state what you want to do
in code with those Cripplets and have the infrastructure just work.
And you'll be able to focus on getting your code run and accomplish the business goals that
you're trying to build.
So the goal here in this diagram is oversimplified greatly.
Down on the right hand side, we have a node.
This is the EVM that has this thing called a cryptodeligate, which handles a delegation of
calls up to the Cripplets.
Cripplets manage the entire security envelopes who are essentially extending the trust envelope
for not just data but execution, which gives you lots of interesting things that you can do.
So let's talk about some of the use cases.
So the most common one people think about are for oracles.
And this is where you're going to want your smart contract to do something based on an event.
So it's a traditional pub/sub type model where you're going to go and say,
"Hey, I want to have this Cripplet do something for me.
In this case, I'm down here in the code, which you can't read,
but we have a little attribute here where we're subscribing to an event saying,
"Wake me up at four o'clock Eastern Standard Time if the markets were open that day,
and if they were open, give me the libel rate and the price of gold."
And what's going to happen is that subscription goes up.
The Cripplet gets the rules for waking up that smart contract and says,
"Okay, I'll wake you up when it's four o'clock.
If the markets are open, the price of gold and the libel rate."
So the Cripplet sits there and runs, and it checks.
And when the event conditions are correct, it fires the event.
The event payload includes an attested value of the libel rate and the price of gold.
And you don't just get the values, but you also get a three-way attestation.
You get the signature of the Cripplet itself.
You get the signature of the Enclave, which I'll talk about here in a moment,
and also the attested hoster. So you have this trust envelope, which is actually sealed,
and you can record all that smart contract for audit purposes.
So that one's the easiest one to kind of get your head around.
The second one's a little bit more advanced, and it's really taking this three-tiered architecture
to a little bit further extent. This is what we call control, and this is where you're using
your smart contract more as a traditional database. So your smart contract,
you're placing, you're declaring essentially the data that you're keeping track of,
and then the stored procedures, if you will, for updating that data.
So you're not writing crud functions, but you're doing the insert or the create
in the read functions for the data in the smart contract.
You are then enlisting control segregation, so full
segregation of your logic out to the Cripplet itself.
So the Cripplet can run off-chain, and you can scale it vertically.
So it won't run on every single node. You can have it run on at least one, or a couple of nodes,
and this usually becomes attractive to consortium networks where you have,
for example, a hedge fund and a bank entering into a financial trade that has to have
greater performance. There might be an algorithm for pricing that needs to be kept secret,
and that can be run in the Cripplet itself off the chain, but still preserving the goodness of
the distributed ledger. So when you bring these into practice, these two use cases fall into
these types of Cripplets. So utility Cripplets, here's an example. Again, I doubt you can read
this code, but this is a smart contract here. I'm marked in yellow where the event subscription
happens. This is the exact same description I used for event, where you're subscribing to
an event for a specific time, if the market's open, for a certain rate, to give you a rate and a
price of a commodity in this case. And what happens is you simply request that the Cripplet
delegate wires up the secure connections between the smart contract and the Cripplet itself.
So it's just like a secure reference. So a developer at design time will reference the
Cripplet they want to trust. The signatures are recorded, and it wires up that, and the Cripplet
delegate can also check and enforce that the message is only come from that Cripplet. So it wakes up
the smart contract to go ahead and execute the code. And you see the code body itself down here.
The salinity code has all the calculations that we're performing. So that's going to run
on every single node once that is been seeded. The contract Cripplet is actually deployed, in this
case, for using the deployment mechanism to actually create the surrogate for the smart contract
in the cloud. So it goes through the Cripplet delegate, and it goes up and creates the contract
Cripplet. The contract Cripplet does all the market watching, all the logic and execution
until it's ready to store its state in which it records the state down to the smart contract itself.
Now here's where the real value is. I always like, hey, I can write this on my own. I don't really
need--why would I use Azure to do this? Well, the advances in silicon and the hardware security
namely entails SGX provides a capability for you to create secure enclaves. So an enclave,
if you're not familiar with what SGX does, it's an area of on the chip itself that's in complete
isolation where you can run code and have data run where it's tamper resistant and tamper-proof.
So you can't poke into it, you can't step on a memory address space to go out and corrupt or
potentially interrupt the execution of something. So this enclave provides a secure container and
then it provides full attestation level at the CPU level that this was actually built
in the enclave and run in an enclave. Now when you're starting to build solutions like this and
you want to get scale and you want to have security in attestation and you're trying to land that
big contract with a bank or somebody who wants to make sure that your security is rock solid.
If you can make guarantees that your code is running in a secure isolated container in the cloud,
full attestation in silicon and recorded into the blockchain, it gives that level of security
that really you can't get anywhere else at scale because you're going to be able to deploy this
in Azure. In Azure, it's been deployed in over 30 some odd regions around the world. There's
several here in China, so you'll be able to deploy these across the application fabric
within Azure. Now we're going to be delivering these enclaves in what we call a cripple container.
Cripple containers essentially an enclave-based container wrapper where you inject cripplets in
there. The cripplets are written in the language that you want to target. So in this case,
the first one will be the .NET Core CLR. That's the open source .NET version,
cripplet container. Then you can write it in C#. You heard some of you might have read about F*.
You have lots of language choices there also in the JVM, which is also very popular in the
enterprise. Then the EVM itself moving into an enclave. This type of scale rolling out this type
of innovation in these massive data centers where you have on-demand secure execution provide you
with these five benefits. So a hyperscale cloud, secure execution enclaves on-demand worldwide.
Same thing for data and data providers. You can start to mix and match. You might have a great
data provider for some sort of data service. You want to create Cripplet libraries that you can
put into the marketplace and make discoverable. You have scalability and flexibility options
now that you don't have and you have them at scale. So you'll have the developer tools,
you have the ecosystem, you have the marketplace and the cloud where you can go out
and not only scale your solution, but also scale your execution off the blockchain if you need to.
So you have a lot more choices. Very developer friendly. So you'll see lots of tool integration
and an ecosystem for ISVs to start building solutions. In a standard way, we're not
getting a common way to do something and it becomes fairly readily accessible around the world.
Something that becomes attractive to larger enterprises. So that has, if you're curious about that,
today we released the white paper for Cripplet's in depth to go out. This again is, thank you.
It is out. It almost didn't get out because of the network here. I had to
push it up to GitHub this morning and I thought it was going to choke on it. It is 26 pages long
but it has some fairly good detail about Cripplet's. But that is coming. We're building that now.
So you're not going to be able to go out and start writing Cripplet's tomorrow or today.
I watch presentations before the presentation is over. I see people downloading code and starting
to try things out. Can't do that yet but you can read this back so you can start planning for it
and thinking about new solutions, new business opportunities for you.
What you can do today and I'm proud to announce is Bletchley V1. This is our Ethereum consortium
blockchain network. Ethereum is the first, again, in the marketplace with a, and this is anywhere from
two to hundreds of nodes by answering a couple of simple questions. So when we went down this
and we started to say, "Okay, what does the consortium network look like for Ethereum?" So we do this
a lot. We have a lot of companies come to us and say, "Hey, we want to start a consortium."
How do we set these up? It's not a private, the private Ethereum network is easy. It's all a node
and you stand it up. So we had to go through and figure out what are the requirements. So this
list of requirements we saw consistently takes about three weeks to get right. That's everything
from network configuration, isolation, or do you want to put your miners, or do you want to put
your transaction nodes? How do you automate this? So it's very fast and easy to do.
So we took this three-week process and we got it down. We eliminated all but two of the steps.
You still have to read up on how to do Ethereum. Once you deploy an Ethereum consortium network,
you still have to understand how to write a smart contract. But we did all this and we got it down
to five minutes answering eight simple questions. And you can deploy again as little as two to
hundreds of nodes on a private Ethereum consortium network, which is staggering. We thought we did
a great job going in from two days to 20 minutes for a single Ethereum node to this massive network
that you can deploy in very little time. So thank you. Thanks, Isaac. Those guys are right here.
They were up at three o'clock in the morning making sure that this. So you can guys can find this.
The link is out on Azure right now. You can find the blog post that will take you right there.
This is real quickly what it looks like. It creates multiple subnets and it puts each consortium
member in its own separate subnet. For example, the miners are on their own subnet. You can't
reach the miners from the internet. You can only reach the miners from the transaction nodes.
And the transaction nodes are on a separate subnet as well. So we put quite a bit of fault into this.
It also stands up a portal, seeds the network with Ether. And you can go out and immediately go to
the portal. We are allowing you to really quickly get up to speed and show your network running
something our customers have really wanted to see. So I want to leave you with a little bit of a
roadmap where we're at. So earlier this summer we released DevTest Labs for blockchain as a service
in general availability. So around the world you can go out and create a DevTest lab.
If you haven't done that, it's very easy. That's where you can see all the, not just Ethereum,
but all the other blockchains that you want to build. BlackCV-1 is Ethereum only right now.
First on Ethereum, first on Azure for consortium network.
Keena Kuda is our security work group. So you've probably seen that community. We'll be publishing
more information about F-Star, the tools for formal verification to the community to help
facilitate and move that effort forward through Microsoft research. And then in sometime in the
near, near future in a distant galaxy far, far away, we'll have releasing the BLETC SDK.
Actually, it shouldn't be that far and it should be in this galaxy. So with that, I'd like to thank
everyone for your time and go ahead and host the show. Thank you, Marley Gray.
